newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian small business sees recessed economy.
newsitem.headline: Australian small business sees recessed economy.

text.p: Most Australian small businesses believe the economy is either in recession or standing still, according to survey released on Tuesday.
More than 80 percent of small businesses saw the economy in recession or static, telephone directory publisher Yellow Pages Australia, which conducted the survey, said.
However, Australia has not been in recession for five years.

The survey found that a net 40 percent of small business operators were confident about their business prospects during the next 12 months, compared with 44 percent three months ago and 57 percent a year ago.

The "net" result was calculated by deducting no responses from the yes responses. The random survey of 1,200 small businesses was conducted across Australia on May 9, four days before the 1997/98 budget and before last Friday's 0.5 percentage point cut in interest rates.

It also found that 20 percent of small businesses believed the national government's policies had a negative impact on them, compared with 14 percent who thought they had a positive impact. However, two-thirds of business proprietors believed the government policies had no impact either way.
Survey economic adviser John Marsden said that in May a net six percent of small bussinesses saw the government policies as negative, compared with a net 36 percent positive a year before.
"This is a massive loss of support for the government so early in its first term," Marsden said in a statement.
